Kent Beck wrote:
> Jeff,
> 
> Thank you for the note. I agree with Jamie Andrews' observation. appendTo()
> in an implementation detail. It needs to be public because it is used
> polymorphically. It should not be part of the API. One fix is to create a
> separate interface just for that one method. Another is to add a warning to
> the javadoc.
> 

I'm not sure I understand the actual bug here. (Does anyone have a URL 
for the actual description of the bug, not just the newsgroup?) but the 
fix smells pretty bad to me. Most Java code exposes far more methods as 
public than it should. If indeed this method should not be part of the 
API, then it should not be public. Documenting that it shouldn't be used 
is an inadequate response.

Often overuse of public reflects a failure to use package protected 
methods, often because the application has been divided into packages 
and yet the subpackages need to be able to access the internal parts of 
the superpackages. Possibly Java 6 will fix this at a language level. 
Until this is fixed most applications and libraries should use a single 
package, even if that package ends up containing a rather large number 
of classes.

Another common problem is the tendency of many programmers and tools to 
make methods public by default. Conservative design dictates that 
methods should start their lives with the most restrictive access 
possible. If a need is discovered to make a private method public, 
that's easy to change. The reverse operation can be impossible though.
